title: 105_hr3679
content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. To enhance border investigative resources on the Southwest border, funds are authorized for the United States Customs Service for salaries, expenses, and equipment. This includes $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. To enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border of the United States, funds are authorized for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. This includes necessary sums for salaries, expenses, and equipment for fiscal year 2000 and each fiscal year thereafter. Funds are authorized for the Immigration and Naturalization Service for salaries, expenses, and equipment for fiscal years 1999 and beyond. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border, including $6,000,000 for Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems (VACIS). For border security along the Southwest border, funds are allocated for various inspection systems and equipment, including mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, contraband detection kits, and ultrasonic container inspection. Funds are allocated for various inspection systems and equipment along the Southwest border, including ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, and remote watch surveillance camera systems. The funding allocation includes camera systems for monitoring suspicious activities at ports, weigh-in-motion sensors for high-traffic ports, AM radio stations at border crossings, inbound vehicle counters for every lane, and spotter camera systems to prevent surveillance of Customs activities outside ports. The funding allocation includes surveillance equipment for Customs inspection activities at ports, such as truck transponders, narcotics detectors, and license plate reader software. Additionally, funds are allocated for Immigration and Naturalization Service expenses. The Immigration and Naturalization Service is allocated $15,090,000 for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest land border of the United States. This includes funding for mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, and remote watch surveillance camera systems to be distributed to border patrol checkpoints. In addition to the funding allocated for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest land border of the United States, there are specific allocations for various surveillance and detection systems to be distributed to border patrol checkpoints. This includes remote watch surveillance camera systems, AM radio stations, spotter camera systems, and narcotics vapor and particle detectors. For fiscal year 2000 and beyond, specific amounts are allocated for equipment maintenance and personnel training for the Customs Service and INS, based on a percentage of equipment costs. The Commissioner of Customs may use funds allocated for equipment maintenance and personnel training for technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds for equipment specified in subsection (b)(1) if it can be obtained at a lower cost. The Attorney General has similar authority for amounts and equipment specified in subsection (b)(2). In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, a total of $112,844,584 and $180,910,928 respectively will be allocated for increasing inspectors and special agents on the Southwest and Northern borders during peak hours, as well as enhancing investigative resources. Additionally, there will be an increase in inspectors and canine enforcement officers at large cargo facilities as needed for cargo processing and screening. In addition to increasing inspectors and special agents on the Southwest and Northern borders, there will be a distribution of canine enforcement officers at large cargo facilities to process and screen cargo. There will also be an increase in special agents and resources for offices targeting drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, as well as resources for anticorruption efforts. The appropriations for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 include funding for increased personnel on the Southwest and Northern borders, canine enforcement officers at checkpoints, canine enforcement vehicles, and resources for anticorruption efforts. The appropriations for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 include funding for increased personnel, canine enforcement vehicles, intelligence analysts, and resources for anti-drug efforts at the Southwest land border of the United States. The appropriations include funding for increased personnel and resources for anticorruption efforts.
